required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Oral Cancer With Wide Excision and Free Flap Reconstruction
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Proactive Swallowing Rehabilitation and Swallow Outcome for Advanced Oral Cancer Patients Treated With Wide Excision and Free Flap Reconstruction

brief_summary.textblock: A proactive speech-language pathologist program can be successfully established as part of the multidisciplinary care of patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and improve patient quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock: Head and neck cancer treatment has developed over the last decade, with improved mortality and survival rates, but the treatments often result in dysphagia (a difficulty in swallowing) as a side effect. Swallowing function is affected by the tumor itself, surgical resection of the lesion and neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy. It is well accepted that pre-treatment swallow function is indicative of post-treatment status and is helpful in identifying patients with high risk of aspiration and dysphagia. In recent years, the concept of "use it, or lose it" has been widely advocated by specialists. Preventive swallowing rehabilitation including evaluation patient's swallowing function and propose rehabilitation and adaptive maneuver or change in food texture. The aim is to ensure safe swallowing and prevent deglutitive muscles from deconditioning. Moreover, aspiration can be prevented and adequate nutrition was maintained through the cancer treatment course. Investigators include patients with advanced oral cavity cancer who were treated by radical operation and free flap reconstruction, and provided them with preventive swallowing rehabilitation. Investigators then analyze the swallowing function, oral intake status, and nasogastric tube dependence rate and tracheostomy tube dependence rate.The participants received interventions as part of our routine medical care, and Investigators studied the effect of the intervention.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Head and neck Cancer surgery not treatment and rehabilitation
arm_group.description: The patients with oral cavity cancer who weren't treated by radical operation and free flap reconstruction,and can't provide them with preventive swallowing rehabilitation

arm_group.arm_group_label: Head and neck Cancer surgery treatment and rehabilitation
arm_group.description: Head and neck cancer treatment has developed over the last decade, with improved mortality and survival rates, It is well accepted that pre-treatment swallow function is indicative of post-treatment status and is helpful in identifying patients with high risk of aspiration and dysphagia.Preventive swallowing rehabilitation including evaluation patient's swallowing function and propose rehabilitation and adaptive maneuver or change in food texture. The aim is to ensure safe swallowing and prevent deglutitive muscles from deconditioning. Investigators include patients with advanced oral cavity cancer who were treated by radical operation and free flap reconstruction, and provided them with preventive swallowing rehabilitation.Investigators then analyze the swallowing function, oral intake status, and nasogastric tube dependence rate and tracheostomy tube dependence rate.

intervention.arm_group_label: Head and neck Cancer surgery treatment and rehabilitation

study_pop.textblock: For all outcome measures, descriptive statistics were generated. Statistical analysis will be performed using the Statistical Package of Social Sciences (SPSS) software version 23.0.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Advanced Oral Cancer Patients Treated with Wide Excision and Free Flap Reconstruction
Exclusion Criteria:
Not willing to participate

Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 2017 Mar 15;97(4):700-708. doi: 10.1016/j.ijrobp.2016.06.010. Epub 2016 Jun 15.

Predicting two-year longitudinal MD Anderson Dysphagia Inventory outcomes after intensity modulated radiotherapy for locoregionally advanced oropharyngeal carcinoma. results_reference.citation: Perry A, Lee SH, Cotton S, Kennedy C. Therapeutic exercises for affecting post-treatment swallowing in people treated for advanced-stage head and neck cancers. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2016 Aug 26;(8):CD011112. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD011112.pub2. Review.

Association of a Proactive Swallowing Rehabilitation Program With Feeding Tube Placement in Patients Treated for Pharyngeal Cancer.
